_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

A?    California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
A?    Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR A?68
A?    California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR A?5189
A?    Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR A?1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Bravante Produce has elected to use PSMWriter©, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1    BRAVANTE PRODUCE, RISK & PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Bravante Produce has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Ammonia Refrigeration - Ammonia (Anhydrous) - 12,000 lb

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.

Bravante Produce has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1.    Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2.    Organize

d the program so that it meshes closely with general Bravante Produce business practices
3.    Utilized PSMWriter© software to ensure that all necessary Bravante Produce employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.

1.2    PROCESS DESCRIPTION

Bravante Produce is a commercial cold storage and packing facility for citrus & grapes.  The facility has an ammonia system that provides refrigeration capacity to multiple cold rooms equipped with forced air tunnels for cooling fruit.  One room is designated as a "precooling" room, while three others are cold storage rooms.  Both kinds of rooms are equipped with "bunker style" evaporator coils that contain chilled liquid ammonia.  Three other rooms are designated as "degreening" rooms.   These rooms contain "penthouse style" evaporator coils.  There are cooled loading dock and hall areas as well.  A computer system provides substantial control and alarm capability.  

The system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from a high pressure receiver is piped to each cold room where it passes through a soleonid valve, an expansion valve, and into a low pressure accumulator vessel mounted on the roof.  Low temperature liquid circulates by thermal convection through the evaporator coils located behind bunker walls in the cold rooms.  Low pressure and temperature gas collects in the accumulator vessel, and passes through a pressure regulator into a suction line.  The suction line returns the vapor to one of two primary accumulator vessels located in the engine room, which separates any residual liquid from the gas.  The gas is piped to screw compressors which elevate the temperature and pressure of the gas.  The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to a water cooled evaporative condenser where the high pressure gas ammonia is liquefied and returned to a therm

osyphon vessel and from the thermosyphon vessel it returns to the high pressure receiver. High pressure liquid from the thermosyphon vessel is supplied to the oil coolers on each screw compressor. High temperature liquid is evaporated in the oil cooler and a combination of high temperature gas and liquid is returned to the thermosyphon vessel by thermosyphon action. Liquid separated from the suction return gas in the primary accumulator vessels drains into liquid transfer vessels.  Operation of a float switch activated solenoid valve raises the pressure in the liquid transfer vessel to the point the liquid can be drained into the high pressure receiver

The facility was built in 2005-06 by California Controlled Atmosphere in accordance with industry standards.  It was also built in compliance with the Uniform Mechanical Code and Uniform Building Code applicable at the time of construction. The system contains numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to a water diffusion tank if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point.  In addition, ammonia detectors are located throughout the facility, and will shut down equipment if ammonia is detected.  Lastly, an emergency "dump box" contains switches and valves to turn off equipment and vent ammonia if necessary.
The ammonia system at this facility consists of vessels which are interconnected, or which are co-located such that a release of ammonia could impact the ability to operate vessels that are not directly connected.  Therefore, the system is treated as a single process.

1.3    GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

1.3.1    GENERAL 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuatio

n, in order to be prepared for a release.

Bravante Produce has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in the body of the program. 

1.3.2    ANHYDROUS AMMONIA

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Bravante Produce facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Bravante Produce has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5    EMERGENCY ACTION AND RESPONSE PLAN

Bravante Produce's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

A?    California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR A?3220
A?    Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR A?1910.38 
A?    California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 A?5192(q)
A?    Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR A?1910.120(q)

Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every yea

r we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6    PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Our company has an outstanding safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Many policies and procedures have been implemented to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Bravante Produce continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter© software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Bravante Produce's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter© tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Bravante Produce's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.
Bravante Produce has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter©, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter© as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter©.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter© to create, schedule, track, and document events, Bravante Produce has also entered into a contract with California Controlled Atmosphere to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation. A copy of California Controlled Atmosphere's service agreement has been included in this program with the support material.

For the future, Bravante Produce now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Bravante Produce employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM progr
am Bravante Produce will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
